caption: You probably know us as Environment Canada, but we’ve been Environment and Climate Change Canada for almost a year now. What do we do? Sure, we give you your weather info so you can plan your days, but we do so much more than that! Stay tuned and find out what we’re all about. We’re giving you access to exclusive behind-the-scenes photos and videos from teams located across our beautiful country.

“Being biologists, we were out looking for great blue herons again this summer. By visiting nesting sites, we can monitor these awesome birds and track the species. Sadly, their numbers are declining, so we’re learning all we can!” – Kate and Britney, CWS Crew

“Approaching Sand Heads, a weather station off Vancouver Island in the Georgia Strait. Sometimes, I go on familiarization trips as a meteorologist, for example, to replace and calibrate weather sensors. To do that, I hop into a hovercraft with the Canadian Coast Guard! You’re jealous, I know! In the background, one of our monitoring technicians and three coast guards unload our equipment onto the platform.” – Cindy YU, MSC Crew

“Puffin Patrol to the rescue! This young puffin (on the right), found near the Witless Bay Ecological Reserve, NL, was drawn ashore by bright lights from nearby communities at night. We band and measure the rescued puffins before releasing them back in to the ocean.” - Sabina, CWS Crew
Spotted: Our mini van on a field trip for bird conservation to the beautiful Lac du Bois grasslands.
"Monday got me like"  Burrowing Owl caught by one of our Infrared motion-sensor cameras. Our biologists use the cameras to take images in wildlife habitats across Canada.

Meet Lynne (l), and Barbara (r). Both women were part of the first all-female Canadian Wildlife Service research team back in 1975, bird banding in the Arctic. 41 years later, Barbara continues her work with CWS. This month, you will find her on Manitoulin Island counting Sandhill Cranes.
We spotted this oddball heron and her mate nesting on a pylon while surveying the heron population in the Fraser River, BC. Must be something to it, they raised a chick there!

Here is a photo of the Automated Weather Station taken in the Callaghan valley near Whistler last March, while the sun was still coming up over the mountains and the hoar frost is on the snow. 
Automated weather stations like this one near Whistler, BC provide weather data for more accurate forecasting!

“It is good to have an end to journey toward; but it is the journey that matters, in the end.” – Ursula K. Le Guin

Dr. Fred Roots had quite the journey, and we owe him a lot. He lived a life full of exploration and discovery, and he played an influential role in the development of Environment Canada. From organizing the Polar Continental Shelf Program to chairing the UNESCO Man and the Biosphere Programme, his accomplishments were many. Dr. Roots is also known for his contribution in writing the Antarctic Treaty—a treaty whose legacy lives on today. He will always be remembered.
📷: @studentsonice

Shine bright like a lighthouse…er diamond?

Many weather stations are remote. With the Pachena Light Station in the background, a Coast Guard helicopter🚁 near Bamfield, B.C. safely delivers our weather station technicians to their workplace, a weather station along the world famous West Coast Trail.
“I AM A MAGICAL OWL DELIVERING A MESSAGE: HOOOOO!” A burrowing owl trying really hard to be a spooky hoot. Happy owl-ween!🎃🕸🕷

This winter, we are going to live vicariously through these whimbrels as they set their sights on warmer wintering grounds.

Working with partners, we’ve equipped these migratory birds with transmitters to track their journey from Miscou Island in New Brunswick, Canada, to Brazil. Knowing where they are going and how fast they are travelling can give biologists a better idea of what sort of threats they might be facing during their travels. @mountallison @usfws

Here we are, four biologists (two in front, one way in the back, and yours truly behind the camera), installing a fence through a small tree-lined wetland at the Last Mountain Lake National Wildlife Area (NWA), Saskatchewan.🛠 We need fences like this one to keep our local “vegetation managers”(🐄) from wandering off the NWA and onto the roads and neighbouring properties. They munch away to keep our grasslands healthy!  It took a lot of elbow grease to install this 3.2-km fence. We worked on it in our spare time, over about 3 months, and we had to start bright and early to avoid the blistering summer heat. (Hipwaders are hot at the best of times.) But at least we had the mosquitos to keep us company! - Kerry

COOL SCIENTIST ALERT! 😎

Here’s Benoit, one of our biologists studying the health of freshwater in Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, using *CABIN methodology. By sampling and studying invertebrates, he can tell a lot about how healthy the freshwater is. *CABIN is the Canadian Aquatic Biomonitoring Network, a network of groups working together to assess the health of freshwater ecosystems across Canada. In using CABIN methods, partners take observations using approved protocols and make scientific assessments using national standards.

Good news comes on Friday! 🙌🏽 The Randle Reef Sediment Remediation Project is cleaning up Hamilton Harbour. Yay clean water! The engineered containment facility (or ECF) pictured here acts like a box that will store the yuckiest of sediment. When the $138.9 million project is complete in 2022, it will make the water cleaner for the fish 🐟 & us to enjoy, and bring jobs and tourism to the local community. Hooray!!!!! 🎉 📷: Bermingham Foundation Solutions
“Have you seen a bear?🐻 It’s #HugABearDay! Yeah … hugging a bear is a little dangerous (understatement!) … unless it’s Yogi or Winnie the Pooh. But I’m just a cute caribou! Can I get a hug?”

“It’s getting hot in here” 🎶 or is it just this carefully planned grassland fire?🔥 Biologist and Fireboss 🚒😎Kerry stands to watch as her colleague Sarah steps back from the flames while lighting up the primary fireline – Woah!!! A controlled burn can help keep ecosystems healthy by reducing the number of shrubs and trees, & removing old plant material that builds up over years.

Hello, Henry here. Our Climate Change crew is in Marrakech for @COP22ma (Conference of the Parties). I’ll be sharing photos of what it’s like to be part of the Canadian delegation and highlights of the work we do.  #ClimateChange #COP22 #COP22CAN  #BehindTheScenes

#CoolScientistAlert  Meet Sue, a water scientist who studies harmful algal blooms, at our lab in Burlington. She has always been inspired by her work. “The diversity of field work and lab work has given me an exciting career in science.” Here she is on her home-away-from-home, the Canadian Coast Guard Ship Limnos. Sue will be retiring in December, and we wish her all the best! #ThankYou

Oh BUOY! What a boat!⛴ Come on board! The Canadian Coast Guard Ship (CCGS) Limnos calls Burlington, Ontario, its home, where it is docked at the Canada Centre for Inland Water (more often than knot). Puns are totally intended. 😉

Taking its name from “limnology,” the study of inland waters, CCGS Limnos is the dedicated scientific vessel for our environmental research and monitoring on the Great Lakes. It is capable of sampling the water, using a wide array of equipment, and it is equipped with an on-board laboratory for the processing and analysis of samples. How neat is that?

New! #Marine National #Wildlife Area: Scott Islands

The Scott Islands and surrounding waters together make up one of the most productive and biologically diverse marine #ecosystems, particularly for #seabirds, on the Canadian Pacific Coast. #Cop13 #HiddenGems

These good looking birds are known for their stoic stature and epic appearance - from Southern California to the coastal Alaskan Arctic. Tens of thousands of Tufted Puffins choose the Scott Islands as their preferred breeding grounds when taking a beak break from a lifetime at sea.

Everyday I’m puffi-lin.

“Hi there, we’re two brand new sanderling #sandpipers checking in from the Great White North. We may only be a few hours old, but we are ready to go! Don’t worry, mom and dad are close by as we get our vitals taken. But first, we’ll get a few leg bands that will help track our progress as we migrate south for the #winter. Soon we’ll be soaking up the sun ☀️on the Florida coast. You may have met our famous cousin, #PixarPiper? Her plumage is a little different from ours, but that’s because we need to blend into the arctic tundra to keep predators at bay. We can’t wait to grow into those beautiful silvery feathers, and to snack on some yummy clams on our own to a sunny beach. Surf’s up!🏄🏽”

Can you guess what this is? . . . . .

It’s special because It wasn’t cut by one of our scientists... Freshwater lake ice is very brittle and breaks into small discs like this one. Our scientists take the discs from the ice corer in the correct order, and accurately reconstruct its ice growth history.  Fascinating, isn’t it?

During their #snowmobile journey across the #NorthwestTerritories and #Nunavut, our climate research crew take coordinated snow measurements.
They found that snow cover was made up of different sized crystals with small fractions of new, recent, and icy snow. The snow was shallow (<40 cm deep), usually with fewer than six layers. Here’s one of their stops at Trail Valley Creek, Mackenzie River Delta Region, Northwest Territories.

#JonSnow might know nothing, but our #Environment and #ClimateChange research crew is full of knowledge! The team crossed the #NorthwestTerritories and #Nunavut by #snowmobile to take systematic snow measurements in regions for the first time. These new measurements, combined with measurements previously-made, indicate the tundra snow region stretches more than 6000 km across Arctic and subarctic North America. Here’s their camp in a valley near Aberdeen Lake, #Nunavut. Careful, there might be #nightwalkers…

Tag a friend who can’t compete with puffins! 
The Tufted #Puffin spends most of its life at sea, coming  to land only to breed during a few critical months. Puffins are powerful flyers, beating their wings 300-400 times a minute to achieve speeds up to 64 kph (40 mph). That would have just about any human puff-in through the day. 📷: Catherine Jardine, Birds Studies Canada

Here is one of the most deceptively delightful predators in #NorthAmerica: The Fisher.

Fishers are among the most effective land carnivores, especially given their size. Porcupine is their favourite prey! That’s one prickly meal.

Here we see one hopping over and marking our bait stick (the scent glands are located in the rear). Then it’s off to investigate our camera as they click away.

#DYK? Citizen scientists play an important role in many of our monitoring programs and provide biologists with invaluable information!

While on a recent vacation to Cuba, nature photographer and citizen scientist, Alan Chaplin, did not know the Piping Plover he was snapping photos of was extraordinary. He reported the band only to discover that this bird had outlived its average lifespan by more than 4 times! The 17-year old plover was spotted near the same location our biologists banded it in 2000. It bred on Cavendish Beach in Prince Edward Island National Park in the early 2000s but had not been reported in over a decade. This resight is extremely useful for our scientists in understanding this at-risk species. Piping Plover continue to be marked in Canada, now with uniquely coded leg flags.

Our biologists spotted 15 species of birds while on a quick stroll into the frozen wetlands of John Lusby Marsh National Wildlife Area for the Amherst, Nova Scotia Christmas Bird Count. Nearly half of them were Arctic breeding migratory birds that reach the Atlantic Provinces in winter, such as the Snow Bunting (aka  the “snowflake”), Lapland Longspur, Rough-legged Hawk, as well as Glaucous and Iceland Gulls. During their short visit, the team was especially surprised to find three Short-eared Owls flying together as a group, a rare delight!

“It’s MY rock!” . . “No, Mine! GET OUT OF HERE!!” ... Just a couple of Northern Fulmars arguing about their resting spot on Prince Leopold Island…nothing a human couple wouldn’t do!

Prince Leopold Island #MigratoryBird Sanctuary supports large numbers of four nesting #seabird species, including Thick-billed Murre, Northern Fulmar, Black-legged Kittiwake and Black Guillemot. The sanctuary is one of the most important multi-species seabird colonies in the Arctic, and is an important site for seabird research. Seabird monitoring has been ongoing since 1975, generating one of the strongest datasets for seabird monitoring in the #Arctic. Canadian Wildlife Service (CWS) biologist Steve Van Wilgenburg and Wildlife Tech Patrick Turgeon were working over the weekend, attaching automated recorders to trees in Greenwater Provincial Park (SK) to assist CWS monitor boreal forest bird populations. The acoustic recorders intermittently turn on and record the songs of species such as the Threatened Canada Warbler, which can then be identified by trained staff to allow biologists to determine species abundance and distribution. It also helps biologists determine which habitats are used by forest birds. CWS biologists use these recorders to go along with surveys normally conducted by trained staff primarily in the month of June.

In March, access to wet areas is easier on snowshoes, and allows biologists to capture data on resident species such as grouse, owls, chickadees and woodpeckers that breed earlier than migrants returning from the tropics.

Meet one of our ARUs! 
ARU stands for Automated Recording Unit and it records the sounds birds make! The unit has an SD card which can record 225 hours of sound! #WholeLotOfBirdSongs. Life in the north can be hard for these machines… bears and moose like to remove the foam microphone covers or try and open the units, and in this case, the jack pine tree it’s on has covered it in sap...#StickySituation 😅

Rhiannon is installing a #SolarPanel to help the Automated Recording Unit operate year-round to record bird calls. #HarnessThePowerOfTheArcticSun.

Maintaining the stations in the winter is much more cost effective, because there are winter roads (ice roads) in the Northwest Territories! #DrivingOnIce #WinterHighway #WinterfFeldwork

Not only do the recordings tell us what birds are present, but we also learn when birds arrive to the north in the spring and when they depart for warmer southern locations. As well, there are some bird calls which are difficult for the human ear to pick up, especially if other birds are calling at the same time (e.g. Ruffed Grouse); these units allow us to record ALL the sounds, including the tricky quiet ones #WeHearYouBirds.

This Semipalmated #Plover, was banded in June 2010 at Fish Island in the Mackenzie Delta, Northwest Territories just outside the Kendall Island Migratory Bird Sanctuary. 
The bird was first spotted that fall on southward migration at Marco Island, Florida by Dave Addison who was doing surveys of Florida’s beaches. The bird was inadvertently given the name “Smile”… #longstory and it has stuck! 
Smile has since visited the same stretch of beach on nearly every spring (northward) and fall (southward) migration! He was last seen fueling up #YummyWorms for the rest of his southbound migration at Marco Island this past fall. #FloridaWormsMustBeDelicious 
We can’t wait to hear if Smile is seen again on Marco Island this April!

Yesterday was the late Jack Miner’s birthday! Jack Miner is a Canadian pioneering conservationist.

In 1904, he founded the Jack Miner Migratory Bird Sanctuary for the conservation of then endangered migrating Canada geese and wild ducks and was one of the first to track bird migration using leg bands. 
To commemorate his achievements and contributions to wildlife conservation, the National Wildlife Week Act was passed in 1947 to encourage Canadians to share information and take action for wildlife conservation just like Jack Miner did. Happy birthday Jack! .

Scientists from around 10 agencies and institutes from all over the world are currently working together in the Arctic to measure ice on land and sea. This is one of the largest Arctic expedition ever! 😲This huge collaborative international effort will help ensure the ice-thickness maps created from satellite data are correct. We have a small crew over there that will be sharing photos and highlights (when they have access to the Internet 🤦🏽‍♀️). Check our account to follow their adventures! 🙃

Photo 1 : Pilot Troy and scientist Christian measuring the thickness of the ice to make sure it can safely support the weight of the aircraft. 🛩

Photo 2: Justin and Josh working on a snow pit to measure snow properties on multi-year sea ice north of Alert, Nunavut.

Photo 3: KBAL pilots preparing to land on the plane on sea ice without a prepared runway.

Photo 4: Arvids measuring the depth of snow on sea ice along a transect. The site was accessed via aircraft.

Photo 5: A view of the multi-year sea ice north of Alert, Nunavut.

Josh, Arvids, Andrew and Justin (University of Alberta & York University) arrived in Alert, Nunavut on Wednesday April 5 to take part in one of the largest Arctic expedition ever! They are scheduled to depart from Alert on 19 April. The campaign goal was to visit 15 sites along a few ESA (European Space Agency) CryoSat orbits between Alert and 88N,150W and perform a full suite of snow and ice measurements at each site. By doing all this, scientists can ensure that ice-thickness maps created from satellite data are correct. Cool right?  Photo 1: Large depth hoar crystals found within the snowpack on sea ice

Photo 2: Justin operating the SnowMicroPen* to take very high resolution measurements of the snow layering.

Photo 3: Cryovex sample team in their twin otter aircraft on route to a sea ice sampling site where they land directly on the ice. *A snow micro-penetrometer, measure the bonding force between snow grains/crystals at very high resolution and quite rapidly!

It’s National Volunteer Week! The Canadian Wildlife Service’s Arctic Shorebird Monitoring Program has been fortunate to have over 25 volunteers assist with our field program over the past 18 years! They put their lives on hold for 1-2 months to join us in the arctic in remote tent camps.

We are celebrating by highlighting the contribution citizen scientists make to our program by introducing a volunteer each day this week.

Today, meet Fletcher Smith! Fletcher is a U.S. citizen who has volunteered over 6 months of his life coming to the tundra to help with our shorebird monitoring work. Fletcher is a special volunteer in that he also taught us how to fit Whimbrel (the bird Fletcher is holding in the photo) with tiny satellite backpacks that tell us where the birds are year round so we can have an understanding of where birds are when and what we can do to help conserve their populations.

Meet Anthony Levesque – Anthony is from Guadeloupe. He is a dedicated bird biologist with his own birding business now. In the past he was with various agencies in his home country working with hunters and government to implement protection measures for species at critical times of the year to help reduce the impact of hunting on their populations. Shorebirds look completely different in the winter – so Anthony is used to identifying them more from their shape and sound than when they are in their breeding plumage in the arctic and are easier to identify. Arctic-breeding shorebirds spend most of their life cycle outside Canada, so it is fantastic when we get to cooperate with our international colleagues. In this photo, the twin otter is loaded up and the survey team is about to head to the tundra!

It may not look like much but over the last year, scientists have been using these new solar-powered satellite transmitters to tag and track Thayer’s Gulls from the high arctic to BC. This data is helping scientists learn about the foraging and migrating behavior of this species, and how they overlap with areas of high marine shipping. 
Recently, a bird with a transmitter stopped moving. The signal remained strong, and coordinates indicated it was located in a remote area of Alaska. Scientists presumed the device lost until a local resident offered to help with the search. Equipped with his boat, GPS, and coordinates provided by ECCC, he found the transmitter on a remote beach off of Iyoukeen Bay – 100km from #Juneau! Thanks Mr. Chew!

Have you heard of Climate Action 150? It’s a project funded by a contribution agreement we have with GreenLearning Canada.

Climate Action 150 gives students a voice in building a low-carbon and prosperous Canada and an opportunity to present and engage with the Government of Canada.

Today,  in a Virtual Town Hall, more than 400 high-school students from across the country discussed climate change with our minister, Catherine McKenna, as well as with Mary McGrath, Executive Director of GreenLearning and host Terry Godwaldt, from the Centre for Global Education. Students presented action plans on three topics – Greening Our Energy Supply, Sustainable Transportation, and Reducing Waste. Students will continue to take action — in their daily lives, at school and in their community while challenging others to act.

A Swainson’s hawk was sitting on a fencepost, eating its prey (a northern pocket gopher) when I stopped well back to have a look.  Although I used a telephoto lens and was trying not to bother it, after stripping off and gulping a few bits of meat from this headless snack, the hawk decided it wanted to nosh the rest without an audience, and took off (dramatically) to find a solitary perch.

Swainson’s Hawks show up for our prescribed fires.  Once the smoke starts rising, Swainson’s will be attracted to forage for mice/voles/shrews who have no more grass cover to hide in.  We’ve seen as many as 9 or 10 hawks in one area that has been recently burned.

Over 300  species (301 at the last official count) use the Last Mountain Lake National Wildlife Area for breeding (180 species) and passing through on migration.

People like Kerry monitor nesting success of these large hawks at the LML NWA.  Come and see for yourself at our open house June 8 2017 2-6pm
.

Meet our Conservation Biologists Karen and Julie and Wildlife Enforcement Officer Ryan. They’re at Halifax’s McNabs Island, home to one of Nova Scotia’s biggest barn swallow colonies. Although barn swallows are one of the world’s most widespread and common land bird species, populations in Canada have declined by 75% since the 1970s. Karen and her colleagues are busy carefully checking up on breeding and nesting barn swallows, making sure these aerial insectivores are able to breed and raise their babies undisturbed by Island visitors.

Did you know that endangered species conservation is sometimes complex and multi-national? This endangered burrowing owl was fitted with a satellite transmitter near her nest in Alberta in 2015.  The solar-powered transmitter allows scientists with the Canadian Wildlife Service and project collaborators to track her movements wherever she goes.  After leaving her burrow in Alberta this bird flew over 3,500km to winter in Central Mexico. 😲

In spring 2016 she returned to Alberta and nested less than 3km from where she was first captured.  She was recently sighted by biologists in Mexico in the same wintering site as the year before, and we are hoping she makes a safe and successful return to Canada to raise the next generation of owls. 🦉
.

Meet wildlife biologist Sabina and wildlife technician Regina. Their work focuses on conserving and protecting seabirds, some of which are at-risk. Recently an apparently injured Northern Fulmar seabird was found on an offshore support vessel near Newfoundland and Labrador. The fulmar features large black eyes and a striking short, tube-like beak and resembles a gull; however it is actually related to the albatross and shearwater. It breeds in a few dozen scattered locations off Alaska and Canada, but is more abundant in the northeast Atlantic. 
Once the bird was delivered to the Canadian Wildlife Service lab, Sabina and Regina examined it, determined that it wasn’t injured, and decided it was ready for release. They took it to Witless Bay where a small colony of other fulmars breeds on three islands in the area. They watched the bird drink and vigorously bathe until it swam out of range toward the mouth of the bay.  We’re excited about this happy ending!
.

How do you tag a snail? With nail polish, of course! And when you go back to recapture them a few days later, don’t be surprised if they’ve moved a surprisingly long way away.

This Oregon Forest Snail is red-listed in BC and only found in 19 sites in the southwest. Canadian Wildlife Service biologists were doing a mark-recapture study to determine habitat type and snail presence in one of the sites. It was a good chance to practice nail polish application skills, and a lesson learned in how to minimize the effects of stinging nettle!

Sometimes, you meet other friends, like this Northwestern Salamander, along the way.

Here’s biologist Kerry, reporting from the field at Last Mountain Lake NWA. While the wildflowers were thriving, this 4-year-old restoration site needed, and still needs a helping hand. Her plan was to *inter-seed native prairie grasses, and here she was deciding which species and in what amounts. Her team sowed and mowed over the course of the season, and soon there will be a sea of grasses for the birds and wildlife to live in! *Inter- seeding yields a mixture of grasses and legumes/forbs that gives the fullest benefit for wildlife or forage for livestock. It’s a good way to improve existing stands of single species grasses on fields utilized for pasture, wildlife, or idle land.

Arctic goose banding occurs in July and August each year, during a brief period when geese are flightless, while they replace their flight feathers. Individually numbered aluminum leg bands are attached to the birds and they are released. Subsequent encounters from hunters across North America provide information about population size, migration routes and survival of the birds and this information is critical to ensuring the long term sustainability of these species. Here, a banding crew joined force with a helicopter to herd snow geese toward a net for banding on Southampton Island, Nunavut. 📸 Garth Ball
.

Roseate Terns like to nest in places with a bit of overhead cover to help protect them from birds like gulls and ravens that may steal their eggs. This might include spaces under rocks or vegetation, but they also might take advantage of a man-made shelter like this one. Biologists on Country Island keep an eye on them to watch their progress in laying their eggs, incubating, and feeding the chicks until they fledge. The marker R401 identifies the nest for the records. 📸 Garry Donaldson

Symbol of Expo 67, the sphere designed by visionary architect Buckminster Fuller holds an important place in the history of contemporary architecture. Since 1995, the Biosphère is a site devoted to environmental action and education.

The museum distinguishes itself by its interactive and educational exhibits as well as animated activities which are aimed at increasing understanding of major environmental issues such as air, water, biodiversity, climate change, sustainable development and more.

In fact, this unique structure uses a number of green technologies: wind turbines, green roof systems, a geothermal system, wastewater treatment wetlands and solar panels.

The Reference Climate Station at Fort Vermillion was due for its annual inspection to ensure our sensors were within tolerance and the system was in full operational condition. After the lengthy 7.5 hour drive to Fort Vermillion, the crew was glad the weather was cooperative the following day.

This site is located at the Mackenzie Applied Research Association, which conducts numerous crop related research. We were on site for roughly 4 hours as there were several sensors that were out of tolerance and we had to replace them including our rate of rainfall, and precipitation sensors. This site is one of a few we have in Alberta that also measure soil temperatures and soil moisture. However prior to arrival the soil moisture sensors were not working. After an hour of troubleshooting and rewiring we were able to get the majority of the sensors functioning. 🎬 Braden Bunce

The need for Canada-focused information eventually led to the creation of the CHC in 1987. The Centre now operates out of Dartmouth, NS and services all Canadian territory and waters that can be affected by tropical cyclones.

We captured this wonderful moment during Canadian Wildlife Service’s First Annual Mentored Hunt, at Last Mountain Lake National Wildlife Area. Our participants learned so much about ethical and sustainable hunting from our wonderful mentors!

With this event, we were able to show people that hunting waterfowl actually helps maintain the population in several ways. Snow Geese, for example, have a current population of over 6 billion. Their nesting grounds are becoming so overpopulated that it is destroying the habitat for other wildlife in the region. Hunting not only helps maintain these populations, but also helps us raise money for conservation, restoration, and enhancement of wildlife habitat in Canada through the purchase of necessary documents such as the Canadian Wildlife Habitat Conservation Stamp.
.
.
.

During the 2017 breeding season, scientists with Canadian Wildlife Service and @ParksCanada counted a record 63 whooping crane chicks in and around Wood Buffalo National Park – a substantial and encouraging increase over the previous record of 49 in 2006. Guess what? We built two “supersites” in Iqaluit and Whitehorse! A supersite has a variety of weather instruments that allow scientists to measure atmospheric conditions in detail. 
For people living in the North, information like the temperature and humidity isn’t as important as they are in the South. Knowing about blowing snow and ice-fog (a fog made up of small ice crystals suspended in the air!) are much more relevant! 
The new sites will help us understand what weather instruments will work best, so that we can improve weather forecasts in the North.
.
.
.

Julie and a number of Canadian Wildlife Service biologists from our Sackville, New Brunswick office were in the field last week helping out with the annual Cape Tormentine Christmas Bird Count.  The annual Count is one of the largest citizen science projects in North America; the results help provide information about the status of bird populations.  These brave employees faced brisk arctic-like winds to record 58 different species! 📸:Garry Donaldson

David Phillips, senior meteorologist at Environment and Climate Change Canada, calls 2017 “the year of too much” – the weather across the country was either too dry, too hot, or too wet. 
He’s compiled his annual list of the Top Ten Weather Stories in Canada during 2017. His list includes everything from catastrophic wildfires in British Columbia to severe winter storms in the Atlantic provinces. “The increased severity of our weather is certainly consistent with our expectations of rising global temperatures,” Phillips says. “This list demonstrates that our communities must become more resilient to the effects of climate change.”

Do you remember me? Back in April, we held a contest to give me a name! I am a Common Loon and the mascot of the Canadian Wildlife Service here at Environment and Climate Change Canada. You suggested lots of great names. I chose “Kwimu,” which means “spirit bird” in many Indigenous languages. Since the name “Tuuli” was also very popular, I decided to give this name to the chick that I carry on my back. Tuuli means loon in Inuktitut. Thanks for participating! 🐤

It’s Arctic Science Month! Cheryl is a wildlife scientist here at Environment and Climate Change Canada. Together with her team, Indigenous knowledge and innovative research techniques are combined to understand how changing snow and ice conditions – driven by climate change – affect the habitat of the Peary Caribou, which lives in the high arctic, and is considered endangered in Canada. .

Summer throwback! In these photos, Hannah and Paul, graduate students from Dr. Koper’s lab at the University of Manitoba, are collaborating with Barry, an employee of the Canadian Wildlife Service to monitor Baird’s Sparrow survival on breeding grounds outside of Brooks in southeastern Alberta. This project is part of a tri-national collaboration between Canada, the USA, and Mexico, with the goal of determining where and when the bird is most limited: on the breeding grounds in Canada and the USA, or the wintering grounds in Mexico. To monitor survival, we are deploying tiny Very High Frequency (VHF) transmitters in Alberta, while our partners at the Bird Conservancy of the Rockies deploy transmitters in Montana, North Dakota and Mexico. .

Would you believe these pictures were taken back to back? 
One of our scientists working at the Eureka Weather Station in Eureka, Nunavut, went for a morning walk. Due to the moon being in its waning phase, the sun and the moon were clearly visible at the same time. The waning moon rises during the night, is visible in the morning, and sets during the day. After capturing this cool shot of a muskox and the moon, she turned around and saw a beautiful sunrise. 📸: Renee Cossitt.

cliffLAND: “…where nature remains wild and self-willed, ministering to our need for beauty and inspiration," - Howard Clifford. 
cliffLAND Conservation Area is owned by the Clifford Family and is a special piece of the Canadian Shield that meets the limestone of the east and south. It is made unique by an underlay of marble that produces an incredible richness of biodiversity. A Canada 150 plaque is being installed on this property to honour the donor’s conservation efforts. 
cliffLAND was donated as part of Environment and Climate Change Canada’s Ecological Gifts program, and is forever protected by the Mississippi Madawaska Land Trust. The Ecological Gifts Program offers tax benefits to landowners who donate land to be preserved for the rest of time.
